direction.raw_text: to disclose the rest of the anteroom. To Camera left are the elevators -- at back wall directly behind switchboard are chairs and a table for visitors. Next to switchboard are stairs leading downward to the next floor. A waist-high iron grill with a gate in it separates the switchboard from the anteroom, a similar grill separating it again from the city room which stretches on beyond switchboard. At a table in the switchboard enclosure sits an office boy, about fifteen, doing a crossword puzzle. The big clock on the back wall shows that it is nearly one o'clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: OFFICE BOY as he bends over paper. We catch a glimpse of the squares of a crossword puzzle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as a reporter comes out of the City Room, clanging gate to behind him. The office boy looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He catches a glimpse of the far elevator going down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's a seven-letter word for --?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't ask me! If I knew any seven- letter words, I'd be something better than a reporter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! Down! Down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ELEVATORS as reporter runs in to the closed elevator door and pounds on it. It comes back, the door opens, and he gets in. The door closes, as elevator goes down. The near elevator comes up and discharges Hildy Johnson and Bruce Baldwin. Bruce carries an umbrella and wears a raincoat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT TABLE office boy looking over his puzzle as Hildy and Bruce come into the scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (with a smile) Hello, Skinny. Remember me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks up; then a glowing smile) Hildy Johnson!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: SWITCHBOARD Hildy approaches the switchboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first operator looks up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to operator) Hello, Maisie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello -- Hildy! You coming back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, just visiting. Tell me, is the lord of the universe in today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is -- and in a very bad humor. I think somebody stole one of his crown jewels. Shall I announce you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, never mind -- I'll blow my own trumpet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BRUCE, HILDY AND OPERATOR Hildy turns to Bruce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear a giggle off scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I won't be more than ten minutes, I promise you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even ten minutes is a long time to be away from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: OFFICE BOY He looks towards Bruce and Hildy and giggles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BRUCE AND HILDY HILDY What did you say, Bruce? Bruce, embarrassed, looks at the office boy, then looks back at Hildy as they turn toward second gate leading into City Room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to push open the iron-grilled gate leading into the City Room. Bruce quickly springs forward and opens it for her. Hildy smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses his cheek and walks through. He looks after her. The office boy whistles. Bruce pays no attention, but stares after Hildy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I said -- uh -- I said even ten minutes -- is a long time -- to be away from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be embarrassed, Bruce. I heard it, but I just wanted to hear it again. I can stand being spoiled a little. The gentleman I'm going to have a chat with did very little spoiling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) I'd like to spoil him just once. Sure you don't want me to go in with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My job, Bruce. I started it -- and I'll finish it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose you're right -- but if it gets rough, remember I'm here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll come a-running, pardner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Bruce.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hildy starts to walk through City Room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as she walks the length of the City Room. It's a long walk, because it's a room that takes up practically the whole floor. The scene is a busy one. But, gradually, as Hildy starts down, one after another recognize her. There are cries of: "Hildy!" "Hello, Hildy", etc., from the men as Hildy goes straight down the aisle. She never stops but waves her own greetings: "Jim!" "Hi, good-looking!" "Laura" "Hullo, Pop" "Nan!" "Eddie!" "Hello, Mac" "Pete!" "Frank" "Oscar!", and gets responses from each of them. One man is bent over his desk reading his copy -- he is standing up. Hildy slaps him as she goes by. He turns around: "Say, who did that?" As he sees Hildy: "Hello, Hildy!" Hildy: "Hi, Jake." She passes a middle-aged woman, almost an Edna May Oliver type, seated at a desk pounding out copy and smoking a cigarette. As Hildy comes up to her she slaps the woman on the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy moves on. CAMERA TRUCKS WITH HER to the end of the room where she pauses before the frosted glass partition which separates Walter Burns' office from the rest of the City Room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Beatrice. How's "Advice to the Lovelorn"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up) Hildy! I'll be a monkey's uncle! What are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Point of information -- what does a girl say on meeting her divorced husband? OR: (What does a girl do, etc.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (illustrating) My advice is duck and cross with your right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BURNS' OFFICE LONG SHOT as she opens the door. Burns is shaving with an electric razor and Louie is holding the mirror up in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BURNS shaving, Louie holding the mirror.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A little more round the chin, Boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There is a sound of the door closing and Burns, without looking up, says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door flies open and Duffy comes busting in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs the phone on his desk:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CLOSE SHOT DUFFY AND BURNS with Louie and Hildy in the b.g.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, I'm surprised, Mr. Burns. That's no way to talk to your wife -- even if she's no longer your wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) Hello, Hildy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Walter. (to Louie) Hi, Louie -- how's the slotmachine king?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I ain't doing that any more. I'm retired. I'm one of you fellas now -- a newspaper man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Editorials?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get going, Louie. I got company.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Walter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm busy, Duffy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're not too busy to know that the Governor hasn't signed that reprieve!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that means Earl Williams dies tomorrow morning and makes a sucker out of us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're crazy. Where's Mac?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's on my phone. He just called me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They can't do that to me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me that call on Duffy's wire! Hello -- Mac? Burns. Where's the Governor? -- What do you mean, you can't locate him? (apparently pleading to the one man in the world who can help him) Mac, you know what this means. We're the only paper in town defending Earl Williams and if he hangs tomorrow we're washed up! Find the Governor and when you find him tell him we want that reprieve!... Tell him I elected him and I can have him impeached! Sure, you can do it, Mac -- I know you can. I always said you were the greatest reporter in the country and now you can prove it. Get going! Attaboy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Duffy, sarcastically) The greatest reporter in the country! First I gotta tell him what news to get! Gotta tell him how to get it -- then I gotta write it for him afterward! Now if you were a decent City Editor --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't blame me. I'm City Editor in name only. You do all the hiring around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah! Well, I do the firing, too. Remember that, Duffy, and Keep a civil tongue in your head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY I don't like to interfere with business, but would you boys pardon us while we have a little heart-to- heart talk?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at Burns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy sits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (together) Well -- But I gotta --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Scram, you guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't miss anything. You'll probably be able to hear him just as well outside as here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mind if I sit down?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUFFY AND LOUIE going out of the door. They cast an interested look back and linger a second. Over scene comes Burns' voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They close the door hurriedly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I said scram!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT BURNS AND HILDY HILDY May I have a cigarette, please? Burns reaches into his pocket, extracts a cigarette and tosses it on the desk. Hildy reaches for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burns delves into pockets again, comes up with matchbox, tosses it to Hildy, who catches it deftly, and strikes the match.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy finishes lighting her cigarette, takes a puff, and fans out the match.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. A match?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long is what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what. How long since we've seen each other?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's see. I was in Reno six weeks -- then Bermuda... Oh, about four months, I guess. Seems like yesterday to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BURNS
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (slyly) Maybe it was yesterday. Been seeing me in your dreams?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: THE TWO HILDY (casually) No -- Mama doesn't dream about you any more, Walter. You wouldn't know the old girl now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grows lyrical and, rising from his seat, is about to start toward her, as he continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (with conviction) Oh, yes I would. I'd know you any time --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (together)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: any place, anywhere --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (half-pityingly) You're repeating yourself! That's the speech you made the night you proposed. (she burlesques his fervor)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: any time -- any place -- anywhere!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY AND BURNS BURNS (growling) I notice you still remember it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll always remember it. If I hadn't remembered it, I wouldn't have divorced you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, Hildy, I sort of wish you hadn't done it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Done what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Divorced me. It sort of makes a fellow lose faith in himself. It almost gives him a feeling he wasn't wanted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Holy mackerel! Look, Walter, that's what divorces are for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nonsense. You've got the old-fashioned idea that divorces are something that last forever -- till 'death us do part'. Why, a divorce doesn't mean anything today. It's only a few words mumbled over you by a judge. We've got something between us nothing can change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose that's true in a way. I am fond of you, Walter. I often wish you weren't such a stinker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, that's a nice thing to say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, why did you promise me you wouldn't fight the divorce and then try and gum up the whole works?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I meant to let you go -- but, you know, you never miss the water till the well runs dry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY A fellow your age, hiring an airplane to write: (she gestures above to indicate sky- writing) 'Hildy: Don't be hasty -- remember my dimple. Walter.! It held things up twenty minutes while the Judge ran out to watch it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't want to brag, but I've still got the dimple -- and in the same place -- I just acted like any husband who doesn't want to see his home broken up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What home? Don't you remember the home I promised you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes -- we were to have it right after our honeymoon -- honeymoon!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was it my fault? Did I know that coal mine was going to have another cave-in? I meant to be with you on our honeymoon, Hildy -- honest I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I know is that instead of two weeks in Atlantic City with my bridegroom, I spent two weeks in a coal mine with John Kruptzky -- age sixty-three -- getting food and air out of a tube! You don't deny that. Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Deny it! I'm proud of it! We beat the whole country on that story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, suppose we did? That isn't what I got married for. What's the good of -- Look, Walter, I came up here to tell you that you'll have to stop phoning me a dozen times a day -- sending twenty telegrams -- all the rest of it, because I'm -- BURNS Let's not fight, Hildy. Tell you what. You come back to work on the paper and if we find we can't get along in a friendly way, we'll get married again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't any hard feelings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Walter, you're wonderful in a loathesome sort of way. Now, would you mind keeping quiet long enough for me to tell you what I came up here for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising, reaching for his hat) Sure, come on. We'll have some lunch and you can tell me everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (also rising) I have a lunch date. I just want -- BURNS You can break it, can't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure you can. Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY Don't tell me what to do! We're divorced -- I'm a free woman. You're not my husband and you're not my boss! And what's more, you're not going to be my boss.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean by that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just what I said. That's what I -- BURNS You mean you're not coming back to work here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the first time you've been right today. That's what I -- BURNS (still interrupting) You've had a better offer, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You bet I've got a better offer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, go on and take it. Work for somebody else! That's the gratitude I get for -- HILDY I know, Walter, but I -- BURNS (ignoring her) What were you when you came here five years ago? A little college girl from a School of Journalism! I took a little doll-faced mugg -- HILDY You wouldn't have taken me if I hadn't been doll-faced!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why should I? I thought it would be a novelty to have a face around here a man could look at without shuddering.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, Walter -- BURNS (going right on) I made a great reporter out of you, Hildy, but you won't be half as good on any other paper, and you know it. You need me and I need you -- and the paper needs both of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the paper'll have to learn to do without me. And so will you. It just didn't work out, Walter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE BURNS It would have worked if you'd been satisfied with just being editor and reporter. But no! You had to marry me and spoil everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She grabs something and chucks it at him. He ducks. The phone rings.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly) I wasn't satisfied! I suppose I proposed to you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you practically did! Making goo-goo eyes at me for two years till I broke down. And I still claim I was tight the night I proposed. If you'd been a gentleman you'd have forgotten all about it. But not you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speechless) You -- you --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Hildy) You're losing your eye. You used to be able to pitch better than that. (he reaches for phone) Hello... Yeah... What? Sweeney? Well, what can I do for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUFFY seated at his desk, talking into phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with you? Are you drunk? This is Duffy, not Sweeney!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BURNS AND HILDY Burns into phone:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sweeney! You can't do that to me! Not today, of all days! Jumping Jehosophat! Oh, no, Sweeney... Well, I suppose so... All right. If you have to, you have to. (he hangs up) How do you like that? Everything happens to me -- with 365 days in the year -- this has to be the day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sweeney.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet. Might just as well be. The only man on the paper who can write -- and his wife picks this morning to have a baby!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sweeney? (she laughs) Well, after all, he didn't do it on purpose, did he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BURNS AND HILDY BURNS I don't care whether he did or not. He's supposed to be covering the Earl Williams case and there he is -- waiting at the hospital! Is there no sense of honor left in this country?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (practically) Well, haven't you got anybody else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nobody else on the paper who can write! This'll break me, unless -- (he stares at Hildy; then a light breaks) Hildy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got to help me, Hildy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep away -- BURNS It'll bring us together again, Hildy -- just the way we used to be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I'm afraid of. "Any time -- any place -- anywhere!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't mock, Hildy, this is bigger than anything that's happened to us. Don't do it for me! Do it for the paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get away, Svengali.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you won't do it for love, how about money? Forget the other offer and I'll raise you twenty-five bucks a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, you bumble-headed baboon -- BURNS All right -- thirty-five, and not a cent more!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please! Will you just -- BURNS Great grief! What's that other paper going to give you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not working for any other paper!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh! In that case, the raise is off and you go back to your old salary and like it. Trying to blackjack -- HILDY Look at this! (pulling her glove off her left hand)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY She gets glove off left hand and holds up an engagement ring for him to see.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you see this? Do you know what an engagement ring is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BURNS He looks at ring, swallows, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burns and Hildy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I tried to tell you right away but you started reminiscing. I'm getting married, Walter, and also getting as far away from the newspaper business as I can get! I'm through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (himself again) Get married all you want to, Hildy, but you can't quit the newspaper business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't sell me that, Walter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who says I can't? You're a newspaper man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why I'm quitting. I want to go some place where I can be a woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you, Hildy, and I know what it would mean. It would kill you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY (bitterly) A journalist! Peeking through keyholes -- running after fire engines -- waking people up in the middle of the night to ask them if they think Hitler's going to start a war -- stealing pictures off old ladies of their daughters that got chased by apemen! I know all about reporters -- a lot of daffy buttinskies going around without a nickel in their pockets, and for what? So a million hired girls and motormen's wives will know what's going on! No, Walter, I'm through.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where'd you meet this man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bermuda.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bermuda... Rich, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not what you'd call rich. Makes about five thousand a year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's his line?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's in the insurance business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks up) The insurance business?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on the defensive) It's a good, honest business, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BURNS Oh sure, it's honest. But somehow, I can't picture you with a guy who sells policies.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I can, and I love it! He forgets the office when he's with me. He doesn't treat me like an errand-boy -- he treats me like a woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He does, does he? How did I treat you -- like a water buffalo?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know about water buffaloes, but I know about him. He's kind and sweet and considerate. He wants a home -- and children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say, sounds more like a guy I ought to marry. What's his name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'll give you a hint. By tomorrow they'll be calling me Mrs. Bruce Baldwin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow? Tomorrow... as quick as that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The quicker the better. Well -- I finally got out what I came in to tell you. (she extends her hand) So long, Walter, and better luck next time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking her hand) I wish you everything I couldn't give you, Hildy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too bad I couldn't see this guy first. I'm pretty particular about whom my wife marries.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Well, he's waiting in the anteroom for me now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say, could I meet him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, better not, Walter. Wouldn't do any good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not afraid, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Afraid? I should say not!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right then, come on and let's see this paragon. (gets hat) Is he as good as you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: OFFICE Burns has his hat. They start toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the door, Burns walks ahead, opens door and walks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Then what does he want with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Now you got me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing personal. I was just asking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT BURNS
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops as he realizes she's not there. The door opens. Hildy comes out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: After all --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't believe this, Walter, but Bruce holds the door open for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) No kidding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CITY ROOM FULL SHOT Reporters conversing. They stop as Hildy and Burns enter scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Hildy follows Burns through the City Room. This time, in contrast to Hildy's original walk through the room, the groups are silent as they watch the two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burns, at this point, has reached the switchboard. He says, under his breath, to Maisie:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy, a little out of breath, catches up with him. At the iron gate that opens into anteroom Hildy jumps ahead, opens the gate and holds it for Burns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy follows him out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to keep pace) And he takes his hat off when he's with a lady.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over his shoulder) What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) And when he walks with a lady, he waits for her!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stops) Oh, I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (under his breath) Have Duffy call me in the restaurant in twenty minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Allow me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (walking right through) Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ANTEROOM MED. SHOT as Hildy follows Burns in. Bruce is sitting on the bench. On the end of a bench sits an old, grizzled Western Union "boy". Ignoring Bruce, Burns strides over to the "boy", seizes his hand, shakes it and says:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can see right away my wife picked out the right husband for herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BRUCE Hildy behind him. Bruce registers amazement at this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BURNS AND MESSENGER The messenger is more amazed than Bruce as Burns keeps pumping his hand vigorously.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There must be some mistake. I'm already married.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (you never saw a more surprised man) Already married! (turning to Hildy o.s.) Hildy, why didn't you tell me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY She shakes her head at Burns' antics, but can't help smiling nevertheless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BURNS AND MESSENGER BURNS (again seizing messenger's hand) Congratulations again, Mr. Baldwin!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burns turns slightly but doesn't release messenger's hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But my name -- BRUCE (as he enters scene) Mr. Burns!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? You'll have to excuse me -- I'm busy with Mr. Bruce Baldwin here. Just leave your card with the boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BRUCE AND BURNS Bruce takes hold of Burns' coat and shakes it to get his attention. Burns turns on him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns away again. Bruce, determinedly, takes hold of his sleeve and pulls at it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very sorry, but I'm busy! Look -- (he points o.s.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: there's the boy. Take your card and leave it with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Burns -- BURNS (wheeling around) I've just told you I was busy with Mr. Bruce Baldwin!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Bruce Baldwin!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Burns, still pumping the dazed messenger's hand, stops at this, drops hand, and turns to Bruce:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The messenger isn't quite sure what he's done but he slinks back to his seat as Burns turns to Bruce.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're Bruce Baldwin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (accusing to messenger) Then who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (falteringly) My name's Pete Davis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pete Davis! Well, Mr. Davis, this is no concern of yours and after this I'll thank you to keep out of my affairs!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY She is beginning to get sore, but reluctantly again she is compelled to smile at Walter's behavior.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BURNS AND BRUCE BURNS (reaches for Bruce's hand but grabs the umbrella and begins shaking the handle up and down) This is a pleasure, Mr. Baldwin, and I'm sorry about the mistake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burns looks down. Bruce, in unconscious responses, helplessly lifts his foot up and we see the rubber.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (he tries to shift the umbrella, calling Burns' attention to it, and offers his hand instead)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I thought there was something funny... You see, Bruce, you don't mind if I call you Bruce, do you? After all, we're practically related -- BRUCE (completely unnerved by this time, and you can't quite blame him) Mr. -- well -- no -- no -- not at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see, my wife -- I mean, your wife -- that is, I mean Hildy -- had led me to expect that she was marrying a much older man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (this is the final crusher) Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I see, she didn't mean old in years. You always carry an umbrella, Bruce?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, er -- it looked a little cloudy this morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. -- Rubbers, too, I hope? A man ought to be prepared for any emergency.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Attaboy! (taking Bruce's arm and leading him toward elevator) Come on, Bruce.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going along, but worried) Where are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are we going? I'm going to buy you two lunch -- didn't Hildy tell you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a helpless look back at Hildy) No -- she didn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just wanted to surprise you, I guess. (as the elevator is about to pass, he calls) Down! (practically shoving Bruce in) After you, Bruce! (as Bruce disappears inside he turns toward Hildy) Come on, Hildy, my treat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BURNS NEAR OPEN ELEVATOR We don't see the passengers. Hildy comes into scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He jumps into the elevator -- in a second he hops out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a look of disgust Hildy gets in. Burns follows and the door slams on them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose I can't call this off without creating a scene -- but remember, it's your last fling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hurt) How do you like that? Here I am being nice to you and your sweet-heart and that's the thanks I get!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very sweetly -- he almost sings it) Oh -- after you, Hildy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: OFFICE BOY He looks after departed elevator and whistles. Then he grins all over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RESTAURANT CLOSEUP - A BEAMING WAITER HE GRINS ALL OVER AND SAYS:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell me it's you, Hildy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and discloses our three at a restaurant table. Nothing swanky -- a place like Jack Blake's in New York, say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She extends her hand. The waiter takes it; they shake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bruce looks at her. She hurriedly changes her mind.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (beaming at waiter) Nobody else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's everything, Gus?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't complain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (studying menu) Well, I can. I'm hungry. Roast beef sandwich -- rare. And some coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shall I put a little rum in the coffee? It's a nasty day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good idea. How about you, Hildy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (discarding menu) Oh -- I'll take the same, I guess. And coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Little rum in yours, too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- just coffee, Gus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crestfallen) Just coffee. (to Bruce) And you, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting menu down) Oh, I'll take the same, I guess. And a glass of milk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) Milk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinks he hasn't heard) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head as he writes it down) Milk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And don't put any rum in it, Gus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gus gives him a look and goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burns surveys the others quizzically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He whistles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives Burns that too-sweet look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (a sigh) Well, so you're getting married tomorrow, eh? How does it feel, Bruce?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Feels awful good. Yes, sir -- we're taking the four o'clock train to Albany and tomorrow we'll be married.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (it's the Puritan in him) Taking the train today -- and being married tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising to the bait) Oh, it isn't like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reassuring Mrs. Grundy) It will be perfectly all right, Walter. Mother is coming with us on the train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mother? But your mother -- BRUCE No. My mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he gets it and underlines it) Oh. Your mother -- well, of course, that relieves my mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bruce) Isn't it sweet of Walter -- still wanting to protect me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (apparently taking this at face value) I know I wasn't a good husband, Hildy, but you can always count on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (a little cookily) I don't think she'll need you very much -- I aim to do most of the protecting myself. He pats Hildy's arm -- she smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'll tell you one thing, old man, she never looked at me the way she's looking at you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That "ow" is sotto voce, but it's the direct result of a kick under the table from Hildy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His laugh stops cold and he clutches for his shin again. Hildy just looks. Providentially, the waiter enters the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He begins serving them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus, who has just managed to come between Hildy and Burns, lets out a startled "ouch".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They fall to.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I might have, Walter, but you were never there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway, I'm glad you two are going to be happy and have all the things I couldn't give her. You know, Hildy is about the best reporter in the country -- and that goes regardless of sex. But all she really ever wanted was a home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'll try to give her one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you will, Bruce. Are you going to live with your mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just for the first year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighing) That'll be nice. A home with mother. A real honeymoon. In Albany, too. Ow!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mighty nice little town, Albany. They've got the State Capitol there, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I know... (he chuckles) Hildy, will you ever forget the night you brought the Governor back to your hotel room and found me taking a bath? She didn't even know I was in town...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, here we are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to pick up again after a second) How's business, Bruce?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Albany's a mighty good insurance town. Most people there take it out pretty early in life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't blame them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm sorry, Gus! My foot must have slipped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a pained expression belies his words) That's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sometimes wish I'd taken out insurance -- but, of course, now it doesn't matter. Still, I suppose it would have been the smart thing to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I honestly feel that way. I figure I'm in one line of business that really helps people. Of course, we don't help you much when you're alive -- but afterward -- that's what counts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see what you mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She sips her coffee and acts surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CLOSEUP - GUS GUS (winking) Good coffee, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gus, this --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She smiles and winks back, and takes another sip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AT TABLE Gus starts to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaves scene, shaking his head. Burns sips his coffee. He likes it. He lifts his cup to Hildy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bus boy comes into scene and stops before Burns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy goes, Burns rises, starts off, comes back for his cup of coffee, which he then takes off with him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You've forgotten my milk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. The milk. Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here's luck to the bride and bridegroom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lifts cup) Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking for something to respond with -- apologetically) He hasn't brought my milk yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They want you on the phone, Mr. Burns.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They would!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (looking after him) You know, Hildy, he's not a bad fellow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at him maternally) You're so nice, Bruce, you think everybody else is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, he's not the man for you. I can see that. But I sort of like him. Got a lot of charm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He comes by it naturally. His grandfather was a snake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) If anybody had told me I'd be sitting at lunch with him -- but he swept me right off my feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what he did to me. Swept me right off my feet -- and left me lying on the floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PHONE BOOTH FULL SHOT Burns is listening, has coffee on ledge and sips it now and then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up, smiles, and finishes the coffee. Then he girds himself for being crushed. He gradually begins to look sunk. He pulls out a small mirror to study his expression till he finally gets what he wants. He holds that expression as he comes out of the booth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get this -- get Sweeney off that yarn and out of town on a two weeks' vacation -- and right away... All right, Duffy, keep your shirt on. Hildy's coming back... No. She doesn't know it yet. But she'll be there. I promise you, Duffy. And tell Louie to stick around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . RESTAURANT MED. SHOT AT TABLE Gus is entering the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He serves Bruce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus serves her and puts still another cup in front of Burns' chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes a sip and almost chokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus goes, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burns comes into scene, looking like a 1929 banker just before jumping off a roof, and sits down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your milk, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I brought you another cup of coffee, Hildy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Gus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too hot?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gasping for breath) No. It's strong. (quickly) But I like it that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking off) Say, what's happened to Burns? He looks sunk, doesn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beaming) He certainly -- hic -- does!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just Sweeney again. One of my best reporters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His wife had twins and he went out to celebrate and got as drunk as a lord. They can't even find him. (he sips his coffee) I tell you, drink is the ruin of this nation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sipping hers) You said it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So -- Sweeney gets twins -- and Earl Williams gets hanged tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just what is the lowdown on Williams?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's simple. A poor little dope who lost his job went berserk and shot a cop who was coming after him to quiet him down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he's nuts, why doesn't the State just put him away?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because it happened to be a colored policeman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (for Bruce's benefit) The colored vote happens to be very important to the Mayor of this town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Especially with an election coming up in a few days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure Williams is not all there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All you've got to do is talk to him. But the Mayor would hang his own grandmother to be re-elected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But couldn't you show the man wasn't responsible?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (there's a sly expression on his face) How?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You could run an interview that would prove it. Remember the interview I wrote with Jimmy Wellman? That saved his life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slapping hands together) Yes, you could do it, Hildy. You could save that poor devil's life. You could -- but -- (the enthusiasm dies away)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: you're going away. I forgot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BRUCE How long would the interview take?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bruce gulps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses him, kisses her hand and pats it to Burns' cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- an hour for the interview. Another hour to write it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We could take the six o'clock train, Hildy. If it would save a man's life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Bruce, dear. Don't you see? This is a trick to get your sympathy. No, Walter, I've been waiting for something like this -- but I wasn't sure when you'd spring it. If you want to save Earl Williams' life, you can interview him yourself. You're still a good reporter. Bruce and I will be on that four o'clock train -- and thanks just the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm an editor. I know what ought to be written, but I can't write it the way you could. It needs a woman's heart -- HILDY Why, Walter, you're getting poetic!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bruce) You see what I had to put up with? She never trusted me! You argue with her -- otherwise you're going on a honeymoon with blood on your hands!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can you have any happiness after that? All through the years you'll remember that a man went to the gallows because you were too selfish to wait two hours! I tell you, Earl Williams' face will come between you on the train tonight -- and at the preacher's tomorrow -- and all the rest of your lives!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (breaking into applause) What a performance! Bravo! Don't let him fool you, Bruce -- it's only an act!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, only an act? Haven't you got any feeling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's either an act on your part or a miracle on Sweeney's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I happen to know Sweeney was married only three months ago. If he's got twins this morning, I claim it was done with mirrors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs, throws up his hands) All right, Hildy, I'm licked. But I'll make you and Bruce a business proposition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not interested.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bruce) Maybe you'll be. You're a smart young man. You let Hildy do this story for me and you can write out a $100,000.00 insurance policy for me. What do you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't use my wife for business purposes, Mr. Burns!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute, Bruce. What's commission on a $100,000.00 policy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, at his age, twenty payment life, a little over a thousand dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what's the matter with a thousand dollars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But -- HILDY According to the budget, we laid out that's more than our food bill for a whole year. Listen, Bruce, I don't want Walter Burns to use me, but I'm perfectly willing to use him. How long will it take to get him examined?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could get a company doctor in twenty minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you're talking!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning on Burns) You keep out of this. Bruce, suppose you examine Mr. Burns in his office. I'll get my bag and go over to the Press Room in the Criminal Courts Building. You phone me as soon as Mr. Burns has given you his check. Then I'll go get the interview and you phone Mother that we're taking the six o'clock train. (back to Burns) And no tricks, Walter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What tricks would I pull?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, nothing! Of course, you might cancel the check. Yes! Wait a minute! What would be his first payment on that policy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About twenty-five hundred dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better make that a certified check, Walter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly) What do you think I am -- a crook?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes --- and that's putting it mildly! No certified check -- no story -- Get me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. The check will be certified. Want my fingerprints?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) No thanks, I've still got those. Well, I'll step into some working clothes and hop over to the Press Room for the background on this yarn. It'll be kind of fun to see the boys again, too. Remember, Bruce, it must be certified.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute, Bruce. Have you got that money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (feeling his pocket) The five hundred? Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On second thought, would you let me have it? I'll get the tickets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But -- HILDY Believe me, Bruce, I know what I'm doing. He'd get you in a crap game -- BRUCE But I don't gamble, Hilda!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know a lot of men who didn't do anything till they met Walter Burns. Please, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctantly) All right. (he pulls out his wallet) One -- two -- three -- four -- five. Five hundred. Be careful, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be careful, darling. You be, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So long, husbands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: leaving. She weaves just a bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - THE TWO MEN They look after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bruce turns to look at Burns -- they look at each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling a little) I never knew Hildy to be so determined before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You haven't seen anything yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : INT. PRESS ROOM - CRIMINAL COURTS BLDG - DAY CLOSE SHOT AT TELEPHONE It is ringing. A hand comes in to take the phone. CAMERA DRAWS BACK A LITTLE to show Endicott taking the phone. He has an eye shade over his eyes and five cards in his other hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Criminal Courts Press Room... This is Endicott... No, nothing new on the Williams case yet boss. Well, you bet I'm here plugging away every minute. (hangs up and studies his cards) Up a dime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S SLOWLY to reveal the other players as they speak. Playing are reporters Murphy, Endicott, Wilson, Schwartz and McCue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schwartz knocks on table and drops cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys all look up toward sound of Hildy's voice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's a simple story. Earl Williams works for the E.J. McClosky Manufacturing Company as a bookkeeper for fourteen years. He starts in at twenty dollars a week and gradually works his way up to twenty-two fifty. A year ago the McClosky Company goes out of business and Williams loses his job. (waving his hand toward Wilson) Take it away, Fred Wilson!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- Williams goes a little balmy and begins making speeches on a plan he's got to save the world. Only he makes his speeches, usually, on a very busy street and neglects to get a license for it. Well, the cops let him alone as much as they can because he's harmless and they're kinda sorry for him. But one day he decides to hold a meeting right in the middle of a Veteran's Parade and the cops chase him. He gets scared and goes into hiding. (gesturing toward Schwartz) Come in, Dave Schwartz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His Honor, the Mayor, now comes out with a statement that Earl Williams is a dangerous character in the employ of two or three foreign governments and the police are going to get him dead or alive. Somebody sends out a tip that this guy is hiding in Molly Malloy's joint. And this colored policeman, Daniels, goes over to pick Williams up. Williams has read the papers, thinks the cop is going to kill him and shoots first. That is all.

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT at the door of Earl Williams' cell. Hildy sits on a stool at the door, pencil and copy paper in hand. Earl Williams sits at the edge of his cot, facing Hildy. There is a bouquet of roses in a water pitcher by the cot. Our first impression of Williams is that he's a rational, well-poised citizen. It is only under Hildy's questioning that he gradually reveals himself.

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't plead insanity, because you see I'm just as sane as anybody else.

dialogue.raw_text: They're very simple. I believe in the Golden Rule. I'm not the first man to die for preaching it. But if they would only listen to it -- we could have a fine, decent world instead of this mass of hate that makes man do such cruel things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How would you go about applying the Golden Rule, Earl?

dialogue.raw_text: (writing) "Production for use only." Well, maybe that's the answer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the only answer. Everything has a use and if we let it be used for its purpose, we could solve all our problems. Food was meant to be eaten, not stored away in restaurants while poor people starved; clothing was meant to be worn, not piled up in stores while people went naked. Doesn't that make sense?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing crazy about that, is there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Earl, not at all. (she indicates the flowers) Who sent you the flowers, Earl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reverently) Miss Mollie Malloy. She's a wonderful person.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing to picture pinned on wall) Isn't that her picture?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning toward it) Yes. Isn't she beautiful?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : PICTURE OF MOLLIE HILDY'S VOICE If you should be pardoned, are you figuring on marrying Mollie?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, she's much too good for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How'd you get in here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sheriff Hartman has come into the scene. Hildy turns toward him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Same way you did. (pointing) Through that gate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gave strict orders that nobody was to interview Williams without my permission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, then, I'll just run the story that Sheriff Hartman is afraid to let reporters interview his prisoner. Of course, with election coming, that might do you a lot of harm, but just as you say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, wait a minute! I'm not afraid of anything. What were you going to write about Williams?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, nothing much. Just that the state had proved he was sane -- and he admits it himself. If you don't want me to run it -- HARTMAN (beaming) Oh, that'll be all right, Hildy. Go ahead, run it. And you can say I treated him well, too. (turning toward Williams) 'Lo, Earl. How are you feeling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, thanks, Sheriff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's good, Earl. Oh, they've got another alienist to see you. He ought to be here any minute. Don't go to sleep, will you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Hildy) Hildy, how'd you like a couple of tickets for the hanging?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in a low voice so Williams won't overhear) No, thanks Sheriff. I'm leaving town tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (just as loud as ever) You ought to stay over. You always wrote a good hanging story, Hildy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's awful kind of you, Sheriff. I've got to get started on my interview. See you later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't forget about production for use.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't, Earl. (she goes)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PRESS ROOM GROUP SHOT POKER GAME - NIGHT The game is on. Bensinger, at his desk, is reading a book. The electric lights have been switched on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mollie Malloy appears in doorway. She moves slowly into the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (raking in a pot) Well, a guy can win when Hildy ain't around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's this guy she's gonna marry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Baldwin -- his name is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I give that marriage six months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hildy won't be able to stay away from a paper any longer than that. Did you see her eyes light up when she came in here? Like an old fire horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She says she's gonna write fiction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if she's gonna write fiction, there's nothing like being a reporter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll give ten to five that marriage won't last six months. Hildy's a newspaper man. She's got headlines in her veins -- the way we all have or we'd be out of these lousy jobs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, well -- Miss Mollie Malloy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Mollie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's tricks, Mollie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MOLLIE
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've been lookin' for you tramps.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GROUP SHOT ENDICOTT Kid, those were pretty roses you sent Earl. What do you want done with them tomorrow morning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy appears in the doorway and comes into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy goes to desk and begins typing away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (tensely) A lot of wise guys, ain't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncomfortably) You're breaking up the game, Mollie. What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to tell you what I think of you -- all of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep your shirt on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Murphy) If you was worth breaking my fingers on, I'd tear your face wide open.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you sore about, sweetheart? Wasn't that a swell story we gave you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You crumbs have been making a fool out of me long enough!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising and coming over) She oughtn't be allowed in here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MOLLIE
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (flaring) I never said I loved Earl Williams and was willing to marry him on the gallows! You made that up! And about my being his soul-mate and having a love-nest with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ENDICOTT looking up at her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You've been sucking around that cuckoo ever since he's been in the death- house. Everybody knows you're his sweetheart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MOLLIE She blows up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's a lie! I met Mr. Williams just once in my life when he was wandering around in the rain without his hat and coat on, like a sick dog, the day before the shooting. I went up to him like any human being would and I asked him what was the matter, and he told me about being fired after working at the same place for fourteen years, and I brought him up to my room because it was warm there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY She is typing away, stops to look over at Mollie, then resolutely turns away, studies her stuff, and begins typing again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, put it on a phonograph!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MOLLIE AND OTHERS MOLLIE Just because you want to fill your lying paper with a lot of dirty scandal, you got to crucify him and make a stooge out of me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys laugh.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mollie) Got a match?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (heedless) I tell you he just sat there talking to me -- all night. And never once laid a hand on me. In the morning he went away, and I never saw him again till that day at the trial!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MOLLIE She lashes out at them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, laugh! I'd like to know some curses bad enough for your greasy souls! Sure, I was his witness -- the only one he had. Yes -- me -- cheap little Mollie Malloy! I'm everything the District Attorney said I was. And still I was the only one with guts enough to stand up for him! I told the truth and the District Attorney knows it! That's why you're persecutin' me! Because Earl Williams treated me decent and not like an animal -- and I said so!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MURPHY (finally irritated) Go into your dance! This is the Press Room. We're busy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From o.s. comes sound of the gallows. Mollie gasps.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you go and see your boy- friend?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (winks at the others) But you'll have to hurry up -- he left a call for seven A.M.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (through her teeth) It's a wonder a bolt of lightning don't come down and strike you all dead!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly uncomfortable) Don't get hysterical, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (begins to sob) Shame on you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MOLLIE -- TAKING IN MURPHY MOLLIE (hysterically) A poor little fellow that never meant nobody no harm! Sitting there alone this minute with the Angel of Death beside him, and you cracking jokes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: HILDY typing away furiously, regardless of this. She ends a page. The sound of Mollie sobbing comes over the scene. Hildy inserts a fresh page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy looks o.s. and rises determinedly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If you don't shut up, we'll give you something to cry about!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She is still sobbing. Hildy comes into scene and puts her arm around Mollie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy and Mollie exit. There is a pause. The boys look at each other uncomfortably. The phone rings. Wilson goes to answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) Come on, Mollie. This is no place for you. (she leads Mollie toward door)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're not human!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're newspaper men, Mollie. They can't help themselves. The Lord made them that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (one look back as Hildy leads her out door) It wasn't the Lord! It was the devil!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (picking up cards) You guys wanna play some more poker?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the use? I can't win a pot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WILSON AT PHONE WILSON (into phone) Who? Hildy Johnson? She just stepped out. She'll be back in a second. Who? Oh, Mr. Baldwin. Well, if you'll hang on a minute, she ought to be right in. All right. (he covers transmitter)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: TAKING DOOR WILSON (to others) Baldwin. The blushing bridegroom -- himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hildy comes back. Looks at them and stares contemptuously.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's he want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wants Hildy -- and sounds very excited.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen of the Press! Always picking on somebody who can't defend himself -- the littler the better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Phone for you, Hildy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going toward it) Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, some insurance man. Are you in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grabbing phone) Give me that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: HILDY
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Hello! Hello! Bruce?... what?... Where are you?... You're where?... How did that happen?... (she listens unbelievingly a second) I'll be right over!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Hildy hangs up and darts out of room. The others watch in amazement.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Boy, did you see her go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lioness Rushes to Defense of Cub.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you Baldwin was in trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably went out without his hankie and wants Mamma to wipe his nose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I still give that marriage six months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BENSINGER at phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, baby, get me the Sheriff's offico, will you... Hello, Sheriff Hartman?... This is Bensinger. How about that favor? You know what: once and for all, will you hang this guy at five A.M. instead of seven? It won't hurt you and we can make the City Edition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SHERIFF'S OFFICE CLOSE SHOT SHERIFF HARTMAN at phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly) Once and for all, I'm not going to hang anybody except at the legal hour... What? Don't threaten me, Bensinger! I'm not afraid of any newspapers. Yeah?... Oh, shut up! (he hangs up; an afterthought -- he calls up operator) And, operator, I told you not to disturb me! I don't care who calls -- I don't want to be disturbed again till I tell you! (he hangs up -- turns to somebody o.s. and speaks) How do you like that, Dr. Egelhoffer? Want me to hang williams at their convenience!
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: CAMERA PULLS BACK TO A MED

dialogue.raw_text: The newspapers! Sheriff, they're the scum of modern civilization.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You said it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're always after me for interviews.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fencing) Of course, I sort of promised them I would give out a statement when I got through here. You don't mind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not liking it) Well, I don't know if that's ethical. You see, all statements are supposed to come from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he'll bargain) We'll have to satisfy them. What would you say to giving them a joint interview? I could give them some of the psychological aspects of the case and you could give them the legal aspects.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he buys) A joint interview, eh? That might be all right. We could have our pictures taken together, Doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, shaking hands. I don't take a very good picture, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It doesn't matter. The publicity's the main thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I suppose so. It all helps.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (just a spectator up to now) Are you gentlemen all through with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm sorry. I forgot you were here. No, Mr. Williams, we still have some questions for you. Sheriff, will you kindly extinguish the lights?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know you are to be executed, Mr. Williams. Who do you feel is responsible for that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The system. But I'm not afraid to die, Doctor. I'm dying for what I believe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. You realize, however, that you committed a crime?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WILLIAMS
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In a legal sense, yes. But not actually. Actually, I'm innocent. I didn't do anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm innocent. I didn't do anything. I never stole a watch in my life.

direction.raw_text: to show us Bruce in police cell. Hildy outside. A police lieutenant with her in b.g.

direction.raw_text: He starts to open cell door.

dialogue.raw_text: I know you didn't, Bruce.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to lieutenant) Let him out of here, Lieutenant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (conciliatingly) But, Hildy, I can't. He's accused of stealing a watch. And they found the watch on him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And who accused him? Diamond Louis! One of the worst crooks in town! Why don't you arrest Louis instead of innocent people that he frames?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, Hildy -- HILDY Don't Hildy me! Are you going to let him out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. You can't. But tomorrow the Post will run the story of that roulette game on 43rd Street that your brother-in-law runs. And we'll print that you get five hundred a month for forgetting about it!

dialogue.raw_text: Now, Hildy, don't be hasty! I can't let him out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can let him out on bail, can't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five hundred dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll take fifty and like it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wavers) Well, all right. But I'm liable to get into a jam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll get into a worse one if you don't.

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stops) The check, Bruce!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right here. Gee, it was lucky your telling me about that old newspaper superstition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking check and putting it away) Yes, wasn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't imagine who did it. I can't think of any enemies I have.

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at him fondly) I'm sure you haven't any.

dialogue.raw_text: For a minute, I thought maybe Walter Burns was at the back of it. But then I realized he couldn't have been.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no. How could you ever think of such a thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I realized right away. He's really a very nice fellow, Hildy -- I found that out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, he is... Look, Bruce, we're taking that next train -- and when I say next train, this time I mean it!

dialogue.raw_text: Did you finish the interview?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to driver) The Criminal Courts Building.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bruce) No -- but I'm sure it'll be all right with Walter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, gee, Hildy -- he gave us that insurance business -- and you promised -- HILDY Well, the story's practically finished. I'll just go upstairs and send it over with a messenger.

dialogue.raw_text: No, you stay here. I'm not taking any more chances. I'll be down in three minutes -- and don't you dare move!

direction.raw_text: . PRESS ROOM MED. SHOT AT HILDY'S DESK Schwartz is reading Hildy's interview to the other boys, who are grouped around. Bensinger is at his desk, a book open, but listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They turn. Hildy comes into the scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) "But the State has a production for use plan, too. It has a gallows and at seven A.M., unless a miracle occurs, that gallows will be used to separate the soul of Earl Williams from his body. And out of Molly Malloy's life will go the one kindly soul she ever knew --" (he stops) That's as far as Hildy got. But, I ask you, can that girl write an interview?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think it's very ethical reading other people's stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't give us that ethics stuff. You'll be the only one who'll swipe any of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I still say anybody that writes like that ain't going to give it up permanently to sew sox for a guy in the insurance business. Now I give that marriage three months and I'm laying three to one. Any takers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take that bet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going to her phone) It's getting so a girl can't step out of the room without being discussed by a bunch of old ladies. (into phone; her voice assumes a silken quality) Hello, Post... Mr. Walter Burns, please.

direction.raw_text: SCHWARTZ
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (embarrassed) Well, Hildy, we were only saying that a swell reporter like you wouldn't give this up so easily.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: FEATURING HILDY HILDY (into phone) This is Hildy Johnson... (to Schwartz) Oh, I can give it up all right. Without a single quiver. I'm going to live like a human being -- not like you rats. (into phone) Oh, is that you, Walter dear? Oh, I didn't mean "dear." That was just habit, I guess. Oh, be yourself, Walter. I've got some news for you... Yes, I got the interview, but I've got some news that's more important. The others are listening, suspecting a scoop.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Better get a pencil out and write it down. All ready? (then with a sudden change of pace) Get this, you double-crossing chimpanzee, there ain't gonna be any interview and there ain't gonna be any story... Huh? That certified check of yours is leaving with me in twenty minutes. And if I ever see you again, it's going to be just too bad... Eh?... Oh, you don't know what I'm angry about, do you? If you come over I'll be very glad to tell you the story of Louie's watch. I dare you to come over, you -- you -- skunk in sheep's clothing! And bring that bodyguard of yours, too -- you'll need him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...And I just want you to listen to one more thing. She gets her story out of typewriter, applies it to transmitter and tears it up.

dialogue.raw_text: Hear that? That's the interview I wrote... Yes, I know we made a bargain. I just said I'd write it -- I didn't say I wouldn't tear it up. Yes, it's all in little pieces now, Walter, and I hope to do the same for you some time!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: FEATURING HILDY She reaches under her desk, pulls up bag, talking all the time. The others are too startled to do anything but listen.

direction.raw_text: She reaches into the drawer of desk and gets some stuff which she puts into bag.

direction.raw_text: Someone points to her hat. She rises and goes toward it. Her bag is still open. Her phone rings. Schwartz answers it.

direction.raw_text: She pulls the phone out of the wall, walks toward window and tosses it out of the window. She waits for the crash, turns back and says:

dialogue.raw_text: And that's my farewell to the newspaper game. I'm going to live a normal life and have a home.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to be a woman, not a newsgetting machine. I'm going to have babies and nurse them and love them and give 'em cod liver oil and worry about their new teeth -- and the minute I catch one of them even looking at a newspaper, I'm going to brain him! Where's my hat?

I don't mind because I was married to you and know what to expect, but suppose Central is listening in... Oh, did you hear that, Central? We ought to report him, don't you think?... Oh, fooey on you!

dialogue.raw_text: Now where was that hat? Oh, yes.
